citation.article-title: Microbulbifer chitinilyticus sp. nov. and Microbulbifer okinawensis sp. nov., chitin-degrading bacteria isolated from mangrove forests
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Microbulbifer chitinilyticus sp. nov.

Microbulbifer chitinilyticus [chi.ti.ni.ly′ti.cus. N.L. n. chitinum chitin; N.L. adj. lyticus -a -um (from Gr. adj. lutikos -ê -on) able to loosen, able to dissolve; N.L. part. adj. chitinilyticus decomposing chitin].
Cells are rod-shaped, 0.5–0.6 µm wide and 1.5–2.0 µm long; both rod-shaped and coccoid cells are present in older cultures.
Coccoid cells are 0.7 µm in diameter.
Cells are Gram-negative, strictly aerobic, chemo-organotrophic and motile by means of a peritrichous flagellum.
Colonies on MA are slightly irregular, smooth, brown-coloured and 2–4 mm in diameter after 3 days incubation at 37 °C.
Grows at 10–43 °C, with optimal growth at 37 °C; no growth occurs at temperatures >45 °C.
Optimal growth occurs in about 2 % (w/v) NaCl and cells are able to grow in 13 % (w/v) NaCl; no growth occurs at NaCl concentrations <0.5 % (w/v) NaCl.
Grows at pH 5.5–9.5, with optimal growth at pH 7.5–8.0.
Catalase, cytochrome oxidase and ONPG tests are positive.
Aesculin, xylan, chitin, casein, gelatin, starch, and Tweens 20, 40 and 80 are hydrolysed.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
Negative for agarase, DNase, lipase, and H2S and indole production.
Acid is formed oxidatively from l-arabinose, cellobiose, d-galactose, d-glucose, myo-inositol, lactose, maltose d-mannitol, d-mannose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, sucrose, trehalose and xylose.
No acid is produced from d-fructose, glycerol, d-sorbitol, sorbose or xylitol.
The major isoprenoid quinone is Q-8.
The dominant cellular fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0, C16 : 0, C18 : 1, C17 : 0, iso-C17 : 0 and iso-C17 : 1.
The type strain is ABABA212T ( = JCM 16148T = NCIMB 14577T), isolated from mangrove forest mats in Okinawa, Japan.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 60.2 mol%.
